subject: RE: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Please allow me to quote the entire statement, which you accidentally cut off :-) ... apply the ... Emphasis on the last sentence. ... I am aware of that
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> > When I try to optimize the speed of my tests, the first thing I do is
> > appy the principle "Don't Repeat Yourself".
>
> DRY is about not repeating yourself in source code. It
> doesn't mean don't repeat at run time.

Please allow me to quote the entire statement, which you "accidentally" cut
off :-)

> When I try to optimize the speed of my tests, the first thing I do is
apply the
> principle "Don't Repeat Yourself". Not in terms of code, but of runtime.

Emphasis on the last sentence.

> It is a principle of code clarity, not a principle of optimization.

I am aware of that but I don't see why it wouldn't apply to runtime as well.
Between code running twice and the same code running only once without
breaking the application, I know which one I'll choose. I'm surprised you
disagree.

--
CÃ©dric
http://beust.com/weblog
